propositions.text: The story is about "Ghost Doesn't Speak" by Tianxia Chang
The text is a TXT novel from "TXT Novel Heaven"
Chapter 1: Old Blind Yi's Ghost Market Ear Record
Old Beijingers referred to "ghost markets" as places where people with questionable goods set up stalls in the dark.
Old Blind Yi lived in Gangfang Hutong and made a living by grave robbing before liberation.
Old Blind Yi's poor eyesight led to humorous misunderstandings.
Due to his eyesight, Old Blind Yi could no longer be a grave robber and set up a stall in the ghost market selling firecrackers (取灯儿).
Old Blind Yi recounts a strange experience in a dilapidated temple where he encountered a six-eyed woman.
During a lightning strike, Old Blind Yi's eyes were injured, and he discovered a giant spider with luminous stones inside that caused the mountain to glow.
Chapter 2: Man-eating Murals in the Ancient Tomb
The narrator's father accidentally killed a snake, and a child warned him that someone from his family (born in the year of the snake) would pay with their life.
The narrator fell gravely ill, and Old Blind Yi advised changing the narrator's name and hiding in the countryside to ward off the snake spirit.
Old Blind Yi had a unique way of eating grilled lamb, and the narrator often helped him roast it.
During these meals, Old Blind Yi would tell stories of his grave-robbing adventures.
The narrator learned martial arts from Master Han, a bricklayer, but Old Blind Yi warned him against it.
The narrator got into trouble by intervening in an altercation, hitting a wealthy person's son, and then hid at Old Blind Yi's house.
While hiding, the narrator was startled by what appeared to be a large tail under Old Blind Yi's blanket.
Chapter 3: Thousand-Year Nightmare
The narrator fled to Inner Mongolia after a violent incident.
He stayed with Old Blind Yi's sworn brother, referred to as "Landlord" (土地爷), in the Xing'an Mountains.
The narrator planned to mine for gold with "Landlord" and his granddaughter, Suoni'er.
They sold furs at a riverside market, where the narrator learned about the local dining customs based on the number of restaurant banners.
They ate stewed fish, and two men asked about the way to "Old Gully" (老沟).
Chapter 4: Me and Big Smoke Dish (大烟碟儿)
The innkeeper mentioned that few people return alive from Old Gully, and "Landlord's" grandfather had gone there to dig for gold.
The two men were interested in Old Gully and offered Suoni'er a large sum to guide them.
Old Gully is described as a dangerous wetland with deep mud and treacherous terrain, rumored to have ancient caves and "earth ghosts" that consume people.
One of the men, a "second Daoist priest" (二老道), claimed to be going to Old Gully to deal with a powerful zombie, but later admitted he was looking for an ancient tomb with murals.
His companion, Zhang Juwa, was an orphan raised by the military, strong and simple-minded.
Suoni'er agreed to be their guide, but insisted on thorough preparation.
She warned the narrator not to let "Landlord" know, as she wanted to earn money to stop him from going into the mountains.
Chapter 5: Strange Encounter in the Rat Cave (乌鼠洞)
The dangers of Old Gully are described, including unpredictable weather, getting lost, wolf packs, and treacherous frozen or half-frozen bogs.
The narrator, Suoni'er, the "second Daoist priest," and Zhang Juwa met for the expedition.
The "second Daoist priest" questioned the lack of hunting dogs, and Suoni'er explained the shotgun was sufficient for defense against birds and snakes.
The narrator expressed concern about Zhang Juwa's weight carrying a pot through the swamp.
Suoni'er suggested using a camping mess kit for boiling water and emphasized bringing plenty of mugwort (艾草).
The group entered the vast, swampy grasslands, a dangerous terrain with deep mud and rapidly changing weather.
The "second Daoist priest" bragged about his grave-robbing experiences.
As they traveled, dark mists rose from the grass, which the "second Daoist priest" identified as "demon energy" (妖气).
Chapter 6: The Cave Army (窟子军) and Flying Immortal Village (飞仙村)
The narrator and Suoni'er re-enter the dangerous grasslands, facing challenges similar to those in Chapter 5.
The "second Daoist priest" asks for his "demon-slaying sword," which turns out to be a peach wood stick.
Suoni'er identifies the black mist as "deadly cows" (叮死牛) and advises using mugwort smoke to repel them.
Chapter 7: Earth Dragon (土龙) under Tongtian Ridge (通天岭)
This chapter largely repeats descriptions and dialogue from Chapters 5 and 6 regarding the dangers of the grasslands and the characters' preparations.
Chapter 8: Ancient Tomb in Luoyang (洛阳古冢)
The story introduces Cui Laodao, a fortune teller in Tianjin who was known for his inaccurate predictions but skill in storytelling.
The three Du brothers, all with lame right legs, sought Cui Laodao's help to propose to the three daughters of a wealthy man, Mr. Gao.
Cui Laodao, despite his usual unreliability in such matters, promised success after being paid.
Cui Laodao's matchmaking was successful, but the brothers' deception was revealed during the wedding festivities, angering Mr. Gao.
Cui Laodao, fearing retribution, fled and decided to resort to grave robbing to make money.
Chapter 9: Monster in the Yellow River (黄河里的妖怪)
Cui Laodao planned to team up with his sworn brother, Yang Fang, nicknamed "God-Whipping Whip Yang Fang" (打神鞭杨方) and "Sai Limiao" (赛狸猫), a skilled grave robber.
Yang Fang inherited a special seven-section steel whip, the "corpse-whipping whip," used for grave robbing and suppressing ghosts.
Yang Fang encountered the devastating aftermath of a Yellow River flood caused by the warlord Tu Heihu.
Yang Fang recognized Tu Heihu as a ruthless warlord and considered killing him but was stopped by Cui Laodao.
Cui Laodao proposed a plan to dig up Tu Heihu's ancestral grave in Luoyang's Mangshan to disrupt his fortune.
They decided to enlist the help of two more sworn brothers: Meng Ben, a strongman in the military, and Feng Dianchen, a skilled thief known for his speed and knowledge of traps.
The four brothers met in Luoyang to plan the grave-robbing operation.

concepts.name: 鬼市 (Ghost Market)
concepts.context: Places where questionable goods were sold, often at night.

concepts.name: 瞎老义 (Old Blind Yi)
concepts.context: A character who was a grave robber, known for his poor eyesight, and later a merchant in the ghost market.

concepts.name: 盗墓 (Grave Robbing)
concepts.context: The act of illegally excavating ancient tombs for treasure.

concepts.name: 眼神不好 (Poor Eyesight)
concepts.context: A defining characteristic of Old Blind Yi, leading to humorous situations.

concepts.name: 取灯儿 (Firecrackers)
concepts.context: Old term for firecrackers, which Old Blind Yi sold in the ghost market.

concepts.name: 蛇仙 (Snake Spirit)
concepts.context: A supernatural entity believed to be a snake seeking retribution.

concepts.name: 烤羊肉 (Grilled Lamb)
concepts.context: A specific dish with a unique preparation method associated with Old Blind Yi.

concepts.name: 关外 (Beyond the Pass)
concepts.context: Refers to regions outside of China's traditional Great Wall, often associated with a rougher lifestyle.

concepts.name: 疯子 (Madman)
concepts.context: A character with mental health issues, whose father was a high-ranking official.

concepts.name: 狼皮褥子 (Wolf Skin Mat)
concepts.context: A comfort item used by Old Blind Yi, suggesting a connection to the wild or a specific type of protection.

concepts.name: 土地爷 (Landlord)
concepts.context: A sworn brother of Old Blind Yi, living in Inner Mongolia and involved in mining.

concepts.name: 索妮儿 (Suoni'er)
concepts.context: The granddaughter of "Landlord," who acts as a guide and has practical knowledge of the wilderness.

concepts.name: 集市 (Market)
concepts.context: Riverside markets where goods like furs were traded.

concepts.name: 幌儿 (Restaurant Banners)
concepts.context: A system of colorful banners used to indicate a restaurant's offerings and quality in Northeast China.

concepts.name: 老沟 (Old Gully)
concepts.context: A dangerous, remote wetland area rumored to contain ancient treasures and "earth ghosts."

concepts.name: 二老道 (Second Daoist Priest)
concepts.context: A character who practices folk Daoism, engaging in fortune-telling, and later grave robbing.

concepts.name: 张巨娃 (Zhang Juwa)
concepts.context: A strong and simple-minded companion of the "second Daoist priest."

concepts.name: 沼泽 (Swamp)
concepts.context: The treacherous environment of Old Gully, characterized by mud and water.

concepts.name: 艾草 (Mugwort)
concepts.context: A plant used for its repellent properties, particularly against insects and "demon energy."

concepts.name: 妖气 (Demon Energy)
concepts.context: A supernatural force described as dark mists rising from the swamp.

concepts.name: 崔老道 (Cui Laodao)
concepts.context: A fortune teller and storyteller, known for his cunning and involvement in schemes.

concepts.name: 高财主 (Mr. Gao)
concepts.context: A wealthy man whose daughters were involved in a deceptive marriage arrangement.

concepts.name: 媒婆 (Matchmaker)
concepts.context: A traditional intermediary for marriage proposals.

concepts.name: 祖坟 (Ancestral Grave)
concepts.context: The burial site of ancestors, considered significant for fortune and lineage.

concepts.name: 打神鞭杨方 (God-Whipping Whip Yang Fang)
concepts.context: A skilled grave robber and sworn brother of Cui Laodao.

concepts.name: 四楞七节打尸鞭 (Seven-Section Corpse-Whipping Whip)
concepts.context: A specialized weapon used by Yang Fang for grave robbing and subduing the dead.

concepts.name: 军阀 (Warlord)
concepts.context: A powerful military leader who controls a territory, often engaging in illicit activities.

concepts.name: 屠黑虎 (Tu Heihu)
concepts.context: A ruthless warlord responsible for a devastating flood.

concepts.name: 洛阳 (Luoyang)
concepts.context: An ancient capital city, the setting for the planned grave-robbing expedition.

concepts.name: 邙山 (Mangshan)
concepts.context: A mountain range near Luoyang, where Tu Heihu's ancestral grave is located.

concepts.name: 孟奔 (Meng Ben)
concepts.context: A sworn brother of Cui Laodao and Yang Fang, known for his strength.

concepts.name: 冯殿臣 (Feng Dianchen)
concepts.context: A sworn brother of Cui Laodao and Yang Fang, a skilled thief known for his speed.

hierarchy.structure: The document is structured as a novel with titled chapters. Each chapter introduces new characters, plot developments, and explores various fantastical or dangerous scenarios. The narrative progresses chronologically, following the protagonist's experiences and encounters.
